none: Letter to Louis L. McInnis from T. M. Scott, February 4, 1886
Letter to Louis L. McInnis from T. M. Scott, February 4, 1886
Box 1 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 1 Folder 22 Louis L. McInnis Papers

en: Letter from G. M. Scott to Professor S. S. McInnis, secretary of B. D. College Station, regarding scheduling a board meeting. Scott indicates his availability between February 10-20, 1886, and suggests Monday, February 15th as a preferred date. The letter requests confirmation of the meeting date as soon as possible.

body.value:
Melissa Texas
Febry 4th 1886

Prof. S. S. McInnis
Sectry B. D.
College Station

Dear Prof. — I
have been away from home ac-
counts for not sooner answering
Your note of Feb 1st

I can meet the Board
at anytime between the days
named 10 or 20th but would
suggest Monday the 15th, then
I could go down Sunday
morning, but any time will
do that best suits a majority of
the Board. Let me know the
day set to meet as early as possible
Regards to Mrs Mc

Your friend G. M. Scott.

**The Transcription Process: A Deep Dive**

Alright, let's break this down. My goal is to create an accurate transcription of this handwritten letter, treating it like a puzzle with several tricky pieces. First, I'm carefully analyzing the image, taking notes on everything: format, date, location (Melissa, Texas, February 4th, 1886), recipient, salutation, the body of the letter, the closing, and the signature.

A few things immediately grab my attention. There's some broken grammar, and words have been skipped. I can meet the Board at anytime… accounts for not sooner… But that's common in this period. The name and signature are especially interesting. The recipient is addressed as "Prof. S. S. McInnis" or is it "L.L. McInnis?" I have to do some historical context here and check for cursive 'L' vs 'S'. Thomas M. Scott (T.M. Scott) was on the Board, but the signature really looks like "G. M. Scott". So I'll be transcribing what I see.

I'm making a draft transcription as I go, then a refined transcription with more attention to detail. I'm focusing on the superscripts, the underlining, and how words are presented visually in the handwritten letter. I'll need to review the signature, re-reading the text, and making corrections on the initials.

The initials in the letter are crucial. The history says 'L.L.', but the handwriting has a sharp top, not a loop. I can't be sure, so I need to check the letter 'L' compared with an 'S' in this handwriting style. It looks like "S. S." The 'L' in the letter has a clear loop. So I'll go with "S. S." unless history trumps handwriting.

I'm having a similar issue with the signature. "G. M. Scott" doesn't make any sense historically, but that's what's written. This is problematic, so I'm doing research on "G. M. Scott" and verifying the shape of the letter. Thomas M. Scott's name has a vertical bar for 'T', but this seems like a loop, or a 'G'. And that's a "T. M. Scott" signature. But there's a reference to "G. M. Scott". Maybe that's a clue. I'm checking T.M. Scott signature examples. No help. Again, the 'Y' in "Your" looks nothing like this. In the end, I go with "G. M. Scott" unless it's obviously a T.

As a final note, I'm checking the formatting, any superscripts, hyphens, underlining, letter spacing, and punctuation as I perform a detailed line-by-line review. The transcription must be accurate to what is being said, to provide an easy and understandable reading of the information. Finally, the letter is ready for final transcription.
